author: By Tammy La Gorce
title: How a Dancer, Drummer and Polio Survivor Spends His Sundays
description: At 14, Sidiki Conde was paralyzed from the disease in Guinea. Now he’s an artist living in Manhattan.
content: Sidiki Conde is a dancer and drummer who earns much of his living by teaching schoolchildren and performing his distinct way of dancing on his hands (he lost the use of his legs at age 14 to polio). When the pandemic hit last March, closing schools and show venues, he lost most of his bread-and-butter gigs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Simon Abrams
title: ‘WandaVision’ Series Finale: Secret Origins
description: The Disney+ series wrapped up this week with an episode that alluded to past comics lore and pointed to possible future developments. Here’s a breakdown of some of the key references.
content: Secret origins are the main topic of discussion in Friday’s episode of “WandaVision,” titled “The Series Finale.” In this episode, the ninth of the season, the witchy villainess Agatha Harkness (Kathryn Hahn) tells the conflicted superheroine Wanda Maximoff (Elizabeth Olsen) that “power isn’t your problem: It’s knowledge.” When Agatha says this, she is specifically talking about the mysterious nature of Wanda’s “chaos magic” superpowers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roger Cohen
title: Eyeing Re-election, Macron Walks a Tightrope Above Swirling Crises in France
description: The French president wants to change Europe, redefine his country and win re-election. But first he needs to overcome the biggest economic and social crisis since World War II.
content: PARIS — In a recent meeting with a handful of foreign correspondents, President Emmanuel Macron of France philosophized for 100 minutes on the record, without notes. He dotted his conversation with Americanisms — “game-changer,” “honest brokers” — that must have had de Gaulle turning in his grave. He dissected French “universalism.” He mused on colonial history. He identified hatred, turbocharged by social media, as “a threat to democracy itself.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kori Schake
title: Don’t Give In to Terror
description: Closing up the House sends the wrong message to would-be insurrectionists.
content: Leadership in the House of Representatives closed the chamber to legislative work on Thursday, out of concern that some of the violent insurrectionists who stormed the Capitol in January would choose this day to once again endanger members of Congress, attack police officers and vandalize the building which symbolizes our democracy. It was an understandable decision, given the genuine threat of harm members of Congress were subject to just two months ago, the continued instigation of violence by the former president and the still unresolved accountability for preparedness and security failures that occurred. Still, it was the wrong choice.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Word of the Day: intrepid
description: This word has appeared in 92 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neal E. Boudette and Peter Eavis
title: Tesla’s Stock Tumbles Amid Sales Worries and Market Volatility
description: Investors appear to be reconsidering the high share price as other automakers offer more electric vehicles.
content: When the stock of Tesla, the electric carmaker, was added to one of the world’s most important stock indexes in January, some analysts said the company’s shares might no longer jump up and down erratically and could behave more like those of blue-chip companies.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Carmel
title: The American Academy of Arts and Letters Unveils Expanded Roster
description: For the first time in more than a century, the society is adding new spots for members, with a diverse group of cultural figures.
content: The American Academy of Arts and Letters, an honor society of leading architects, artists, composers and writers, announced 33 new members on Friday as part of an effort to expand and diversify.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Fandos
title: Former impeachment manager sues Trump for ‘incitement to riot,’ terrorism and other charges related to the Capitol attack.
description: The suit by Representative Eric Swalwell accuses former President Donald J. Trump and several allies of inciting the Jan. 6 attack and conspiring with rioters to try to prevent Congress from formalizing President Biden’s victory.
content: A House Democrat who unsuccessfully prosecuted Donald J. Trump at his impeachment trial last month sued him in federal court on Friday for acts of terrorism and incitement to riot, attempting to use the justice system to punish the former president for his role in the Jan. 6 assault on the Capitol.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patricia Cohen
title: Job Market Picks Up Strength, Led by Food and Drink
description: U.S. employers added 379,000 to their payrolls in February, increasing hopes that vaccinations and reopenings are giving the economic recovery a firmer grip.
content: Driven by unexpectedly large job gains at the nation’s restaurants and bars, the labor market picked up strength in February, raising hopes that the economic recovery was taking hold more firmly.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Timothy Egan
title: Seeking Connection in a New Normal
description: With vaccines for all on the horizon, we will have to find our way back from grief and loneliness.
content: And so we emerge, blinking after lockdown, in the strange sunlight of community. After a year of death, a season of hope is suddenly before us, ushered in by President Biden’s promise of enough vaccines for every American adult by the end of May.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Horowitz and Jane Arraf
title: Francis Begins Visit to Iraq, in ‘Duty to a Land Martyred’
description: The pope’s four-day trip is intended to nurture ties with Shiite Muslims and encourage a Christian population decimated by years of strife.
content: BAGHDAD — Pope Francis made an audacious return to the world stage in the midst of the pandemic on Friday when he became the first leader of the Roman Catholic church to visit Iraq, seeking to help heal a nation uniquely wounded by violent sectarianism, foreign adventurism and the persecution of minority populations, including his own Christian flock.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Apoorva Mandavilli
title: In Oregon, Scientists Find a Virus Variant With a Worrying Mutation
description: In a single sample, geneticists discovered a version of the coronavirus first identified in Britain with a mutation originally reported in South Africa.
content: Scientists in Oregon have spotted a homegrown version of a fast-spreading variant of the coronavirus that first surfaced in Britain — but now combined with a mutation that may make the variant less susceptible to vaccines.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren Sloss
title: To Stay or Go? Even With Vaccines, Travel Planning Remains Complicated
description: Welcome to the next phase of travel: the post-vaccine era. Or maybe the mid-vaccine era is more accurate. Whatever you call it, planning couldn’t be more confusing.
content: Kristin Botuchis booked the tickets last month, almost on impulse. Two round-trip seats to London from Seattle for $1,200 in July; the perfect start to a dreamy European vacation that would include France, Italy and Greece. She found herself clicking through the Icelandic Air website and entering her information, “just to see what would happen.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Troy Closson
title: They Spent 24 Years Behind Bars. Then the Case Fell Apart.
description: A judge threw out the murder convictions of three New York men on Friday and admonished prosecutors for withholding evidence that cast serious doubt on their guilt.
content: On the weekend before Christmas in 1996, a shop owner was opening his check-cashing store in East Elmhurst, Queens, alongside an off-duty police officer who was working security, when the two were ambushed by a group of men, shot and killed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Karan Deep Singh
title: The World Needs Syringes. He Jumped In to Make 5,900 Per Minute.
description: Rajiv Nath’s family-run Hindustan Syringes bets it can help meet the pandemic need for billions of barrels and needles.
content: BALLABGARH, India — In late November, an urgent email popped up in the inbox of Hindustan Syringes & Medical Devices, one of the world’s largest syringe makers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Trish Bendix
title: Jimmy Fallon: Ron Johnson Could Replace Ted Cruz as Most Hated Senator
description: The “Tonight Show” host joked that the Wisconsin Republican could be more detested for at least the 10 hours that Senate clerks read the 628-page stimulus bill aloud, as Johnson demanded.
content: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. We’re all stuck at home at the moment, so here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeremy Engle
title: Lesson of the Day: ‘Dr. Seuss Books Are Pulled, and a “Cancel Culture” Controversy Erupts’
description: In this lesson, students will explore the debate over whether and how an author’s works should be posthumously curated to reflect evolving attitudes.
content: Featured Article: “Dr. Seuss Books Are Pulled, and a ‘Cancel Culture’ Controversy Erupts” by Alexandra Alter and Elizabeth A. Harris
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ruth Graham
title: Americans are increasingly willing to get vaccinated, according to a new survey.
description: Sixty-nine percent of the public now plans to get vaccinated — or already has — up from 60 percent who said in November that they intended to pursue it.
content: Vaccine hesitancy has been a concern among U.S. public health experts for months now. But evidence increasingly suggests that as vaccination rates increase, many unvaccinated Americans are becoming more comfortable with the idea of receiving the shot themselves.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lindsay Talbot
title: A Dramatic Necklace That Nods to Antiquity and the Future
description: This new design by David Webb pays homage to a decadent jade pendant that the atelier’s founder dreamed up for a client in 1972.
content: Born in 1925 in Asheville, N.C., the jewelry designer David Webb began his career at 14 as an apprentice at his uncle’s silversmith workshop, soldering brooches and copper ashtrays. When he turned 17, Webb moved to Manhattan and took a job as a repairman in the city’s diamond district before setting up his own store on 47th Street in 1948. There, he sold giant enameled cocktail rings and earrings in the shape of snail shells, tigers and frogs, studded with sapphires, emeralds and rubies. His designs quickly caught the eye of discerning ladies of the moment like Doris Duke and Wallis Simpson, the Duchess of Windsor.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amy Qin
title: China’s Plan to Win in a Post-Pandemic World
description: The message at the National People’s Congress was one of optimism about the strength of its economy and of struggle against an array of internal and external challenges.
content: China unveiled a road map for cementing its rise in a post-Covid world as it opened one of its biggest political events of the year on Friday, casting its success against the coronavirus as evidence of the superiority of its top-down leadership while warning of threats at home and abroad.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steven Rattner
title: Too Many Smart People Are Being Too Dismissive of Inflation
description: Fears were overblown for years. But let’s not be blasé about how hard it could be to halt high prices if they haunt us again.
content: We are all, to one degree or another, shaped by early experiences.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charlie Savage
title: Biden Seeks Update for a Much-Stretched Law That Authorizes the War on Terrorism
description: The legal basis for the war against Al Qaeda and its successors is aging and frayed, but how to replace it has long bedeviled lawmakers.
content: WASHINGTON — President Biden wants to work with Congress to repeal and replace a war authorization law passed shortly after the Sept. 11, 2001, attacks, White House officials said on Friday. That law has been stretched across four administrations to permit open-ended combat against Islamist militant groups scattered across the world.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Gelles
title: ‘There Is a Bigger Role’: A C.E.O. Pushes Diversity
description: Tim Ryan, a white man and the U.S. chairman and senior partner at PwC, has made equity and inclusion a focus of the firm.
content: Not many accountants moonlight as activists. But Tim Ryan, the senior partner at PwC, has spent the past five years trying to make his company a model inclusive workplace, and advocating for more diversity in the rest of corporate America.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roni Caryn Rabin
title: The Virus Spread Where Restaurants Reopened or Mask Mandates Were Absent
description: C.D.C. researchers found that coronavirus infections and death rates rose in U.S. counties permitting in-person dining or not requiring masks.
content: Even as officials in Texas and Mississippi lifted statewide mask mandates, researchers at the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention on Friday offered fresh evidence of the importance of face coverings, reporting that mask-wearing mandates were linked to fewer infections with the coronavirus and Covid-19 deaths in counties across the United States.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brandon Yu
title: Eddie Huang: Filmmaker Was on His List of Things to Do Even Before Chef
description: He discusses his debut drama, “Boogie”; what moving to Taiwan showed him about America; and what it was like to work with Pop Smoke, a star of his movie.
content: There was a time before Eddie Huang became Eddie Huang, the outspoken restaurateur, travel show host and author who once seemed ready to burn down “Fresh Off the Boat,” the network sitcom inspired by his own childhood. In that earlier moment, the aftermath of the recession, he was simply hustling in New York, begrudgingly working at a law firm while selling weed and streetwear on the side. The day he was laid off, he had a moment of clarity and wrote out a list of six things he wanted to do with his life.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jorge Ramos
title: Why Has There Been a Spike of Anti-Asian Hate?
description: A small yet aggressive segment of America refuses to accept that the country is made up of people from many different backgrounds.
content: Pandemics fade. Racism does not. And when a president like Donald Trump unfairly blames an entire ethnic group for the coronavirus pandemic crisis, it can embolden discrimination and violence.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas Rogers
title: When Europe’s Theaters Reopen, Will Fans Return?
description: People from across the continent told us about the ups and downs — mostly downs — of loving and streaming theater during a pandemic.
content: With most European countries lurching between lockdowns and reopenings over the last year, it has been a disruptive time for the continent’s many theater fans.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Sullivan
title: Here’s How to Give to Women’s Causes
description: While a variety of charitable organizations help women and girls, experts offer advice on finding ones that have a sharper focus.
content: Interest in supporting nonprofit groups that help women and girls has grown in the last year, the groups’ leaders and philanthropic advisers say, some of it the result of a younger generation’s push for parents to focus on the cause.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roni Caryn Rabin
title: The C.D.C. links restaurant dining and a lack of mask mandates to the virus’s spread in the U.S.
description: As officials in Texas and Mississippi lifted statewide mask requirements, researchers at the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention offered a new study with fresh evidence of masks’ importance.
content: As officials in Texas and Mississippi lifted statewide mask mandates, researchers at the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention offered fresh evidence of the importance of mask use in a new study on Friday. Wearing masks, the study reported, was linked to fewer infections with the coronavirus and Covid-19 deaths in counties across the United States.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marc Santora
title: In Pictures: Pope Francis in Iraq
description: As the pope makes a three-day trip to Iraq, a look at images of the historic moment.
content: Pope John Paul II had to cancel plans to visit Iraq at the turn of this century as escalating tensions with the United States undermined negotiations with Saddam Hussein for a papal visit. Pope Benedict XVI had to cancel his plans because of security concerns.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cecilia Kang
title: A Leading Critic of Big Tech Will Join the White House
description: Tim Wu’s appointment to the National Economic Council signals a confrontational approach by the Biden administration.
content: WASHINGTON — President Biden on Friday named Tim Wu, a Columbia University law professor, to the National Economic Council as a special assistant to the president for technology and competition policy, putting one of the most outspoken critics of Big Tech’s power into the administration.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Gorman
title: Some Scientists Question W.H.O. Inquiry Into the Coronavirus Pandemic’s Origins
description: Those who still suspect the outbreak in China may have been caused by a lab leak or accident are pressing for an independent investigation.
content: A small group of scientists and others who believe the novel coronavirus that spawned the pandemic could have originated from a lab leak or accident is calling for an inquiry independent of the World Health Organization’s team of independent experts sent to China last month.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anemona Hartocollis
title: Images of Slaves Are Property of Harvard, Not a Descendant, Judge Rules
description: The woman who says the enslaved people are her ancestors plans to appeal the decision “about the patriarch of a family, a subject of bedtime stories.”
content: A Massachusetts judge has dismissed a lawsuit by a woman claiming that she, not Harvard University, is the rightful owner of haunting images of an enslaved father and daughter who she says were her ancestors.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Remy Tumin and Jeremiah M. Bogert, Jr
title: Stimulus, Syringe Shortage, Harry and Meghan: Your Friday Evening Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
content: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luke Broadwater, Zolan Kanno-Youngs and John Ismay
title: Capitol Police Chief Asks to Extend National Guard Presence
description: The formal request came only after a disconnect between the chief and the board that oversees her agency, underscoring the bureaucracy and communication breakdowns that have hampered security.
content: WASHINGTON — The acting chief of the Capitol Police formally asked the Defense Department on Thursday to keep thousands of National Guard troops on Capitol Hill beyond their scheduled departure next week as she warned of an increase in threats against lawmakers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isaac Aronow
title: Many Indulgences
description: Sridhar Bhagavathula opens our solving weekend.
content: FRIDAY PUZZLE — Sridhar Bhagavathula makes his New York Times debut here, and what an entrance! This is a simultaneously impressive and difficult Friday puzzle that made me sweat a bit. Don’t let that dissuade you, though, as your perseverance will be handsomely rewarded. This puzzle is an excellent reminder of why I love themeless puzzles, and I hope you’ll enjoy it as much as I did.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Robertson
title: Teen Vogue Selects Its Next Top Editor, the Political Reporter Alexi McCammond
description: Ms. McCammond, 27, covered the 2018 midterm elections and Joseph R. Biden’s presidential campaign for Axios.
content: Alexi McCammond, a political reporter at Axios, will be the next editor in chief of Teen Vogue, Condé Nast announced Friday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Siraad Dirshe
title: Black Women Are Knitting Their Way Into History
description: Drawing on a long history as seamstresses and makers, Black knitters are grabbing their needles and shifting perceptions.
content: “I was definitely inspired by other people making their bread,” said Ryan Norville, a Brooklyn-based florist. She was talking about the desire that seized her, over the last year, to start making things while stuck at home during the pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ian Austen
title: Why the Canadian Housing Market Is Soaring in the Pandemic
description: The head of the Canada Mortgage and Housing Corporation apologized for forecasting a big drop in housing prices last year.
content: This week began with an unusual apology. Evan Siddall, the president and chief executive of the Canada Mortgage and Housing Corporation, took to Twitter to acknowledge that the federal agency had erred last year when it forecast that the pandemic-induced economic collapse might cause house prices to fall by as much as 18 percent.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma Bubola
title: Anna Majani, Grande Dame of Fine Chocolate, Dies at 85
description: She turned chocolates from her family company, founded in the 18th century, into design objects. She died of Covid-19.
content: This obituary is part of a series about people who have died in the coronavirus pandemic. Read about others here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michelle Goldberg
title: The Israeli Feminist Trying to Save Liberal Zionism
description: Can Merav Michaeli rescue Israel’s Labor Party?
content: When Merav Michaeli, a pathbreaking feminist, was elected head of Israel’s Labor Party in January, some people offered her condolences. Labor was once Israel’s governing party, the home of many of the country’s iconic leaders: David Ben-Gurion, Golda Meir, Yitzhak Rabin. It ruled continuously from Israel’s founding in 1948 until 1977, and then a few more times after that.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Genzlinger
title: Bill C. Davis, Who Had a Hit Play With ‘Mass Appeal,’ Dies at 69
description: He was an unknown playwright in his 20s when his comic drama about a priest and a seminarian drew raves off and on Broadway. It was turned into a movie.
content: Bill C. Davis, whose play “Mass Appeal” was a hit both off and on Broadway in the early 1980s and has been performed countless times since, died on Feb. 26 in Torrington, Conn. He was 69.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew E. Kramer
title: U.S. Sanctions Key Ukrainian Oligarch
description: The Biden administration sees cleaning up corruption in Ukraine as the best protection against Russian influence.
content: MOSCOW — The United States placed sanctions Friday on a Ukrainian business tycoon seen as the most powerful figure in the country outside of the government, signaling an aggressive new approach by the Biden administration to dealing with corruption in Ukraine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anna Schaverien
title: British Law Highlights Parental Leave for Lawmakers
description: Britain approved a measure allowing senior government ministers to take maternity leave without penalty. But some countries make no provisions for lawmakers who are new parents.
content: Measures that grant workers paid time off when they become parents have not always benefited the lawmakers who have created the rules.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Glenn Thrush
title: For Trump, email is the new Twitter.
description: Friday’s positive jobs report might have been a day of exclamation points and all-caps self-congratulation for Donald J. Trump if he were A) still president, and B) still allowed to post on Twitter.
content: Friday’s positive jobs report might have been a day of exclamation points and all-caps self-congratulation for Donald J. Trump if he were A) still president, and B) still allowed to post on Twitter.

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Your Friday Briefing
description: The female heroes of Myanmar’s protests.
content: The hundreds of thousands of women at the forefront of Myanmar’s protest movement are sending a powerful rebuke to the country’s military junta.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Clark
title: Your Morning Granola Just Got an Upgrade
description: Filled with coconut and dried cherries, these breakfast treats from Frenchette Bakery are wholesome enough for breakfast, and sweet enough for dessert.
content: I’d never object to eating a regular cookie for breakfast. But I’d always thought a breakfast cookie for dessert would make me sad.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amanda Taub
title: They Were Journalists, and Women, and Targeted for Both
description: As Afghanistan enters a desperate chapter, with U.S. troops potentially on the way out, insurgents are pressing a deadly campaign to silence the media and keep women home.
content: You can tell a lot about a country by the reasons its journalists get attacked.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Will Wright
title: After decades of familiar promises, coal communities remain skeptical about Biden’s vows.
description: From a porch in Martin County, Ky., in 1964, President Lyndon B. Johnson declared a war on poverty. Decades later, President Barack Obama dedicated millions of dollars to work force development projects in Appalachia. President Donald J. Trump even pledged the impossible: a revival of the region’s faltering coal industry.
content: From a porch in Martin County, Ky., in 1964, President Lyndon B. Johnson declared a war on poverty. Decades later, President Barack Obama dedicated millions of dollars to work force development projects in Appalachia. President Donald J. author: By Ezra Klein
title: Stop. Breathe. We Can’t Keep Working Like This.
description: Cal Newport explains how Slack and Gmail are making us miserable — and what to do about it.
content: We were promised, with the internet, a productivity revolution. We were told that we’d get more done, in less time, with less stress. Instead, we got always-on communication, the dissolution of the boundaries between work and home, the feeling of constantly being behind, lackluster productivity numbers, and, to be fair, reaction GIFs. What went wrong?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Wagner
title: A Buddy Comedy in Left Field
description: Clint Frazier of the Yankees came into a league a bit too spicy. Then he took the job of Brett Gardner, the guy who helped him cool down. No hard feelings.
content: TAMPA, Fla. — If the current version of Clint Frazier, more polished on and off the field, could communicate with himself from two or three years ago, he would have many lessons to impart.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Cochrane and Catie Edmondson
title: Minimum wage increase fails as 7 Democrats vote against the measure.
description: Progressive Democrats sought to add the provision, which would have raised the wage to $15 an hour by 2025, to the stimulus package.
content: The Senate rejected a bid by Democrats to advance an increase the federal minimum wage as part of President Biden’s $1.9 trillion stimulus plan, with senators in both parties registering their opposition to the move.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jon Pareles, Jon Caramanica and Giovanni Russonello
title: St. Vincent’s Synth-Funk ‘Pain,’ and 9 More New Songs
description: Hear tracks by Drake featuring Rick Ross, Bruno Mars and Anderson .Paak, Bebe Rexha and others.
content: Every Friday, pop critics for The New York Times weigh in on the week’s most notable new songs and videos. Just want the music? Listen to the Playlist on Spotify here (or find our profile: nytimes). Like what you hear? Let us know at theplaylist@nytimes.com and sign up for our Louder newsletter, a once-a-week blast of our pop music coverage.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Sifton
title: What to Cook This Weekend
description: Set aside some time to cook, whether you make a tater tot casserole, oden with homemade shrimp balls, or a comforting braciole.
content: Good morning. Here’s some exciting news from the virtual headquarters of NYT Cooking: Our “No-Recipe Recipes” cookbook is now available for pre-order. (The book comes out on March 16, and, that evening, Melissa Clark and I will talk about it over the internet, if you’d like to join.) There’s an excerpt in The New York Times Magazine this weekend and, with it, a no-recipe recipe for a dinner of smothered pork chops with sautéed greens and lemony mashed potatoes (above). I hope you make that dinner this weekend and revel in the pleasures of improvisatory cooking. At this stage of the pandemic, it should come naturally. You’ve been cooking so much!
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Keith Bradsher, Chris Buckley and Vivian Wang
title: A Confident China Promises Robust Growth and a Hard Line on Hong Kong
description: Officials said the economy would grow by more than 6 percent this year. They also pushed ahead with an electoral overhaul in Hong Kong that would cripple the opposition.
content: BEIJING — China sent a forceful message on Friday advancing the top leader Xi Jinping’s sweeping agenda for the country’s economic and political ascent while drawing a hard line against challenges to Communist Party rule.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ginia Bellafante
title: Why My Teenage Self Gave Woody Allen a Pass
description: The urbane paradise of “Manhattan” looks a lot different through the lens of the new HBO documentary “Allen v. Farrow.”
content: Between the years 1979, when it opened in theaters, and 1984, I saw “Manhattan” 11 times, after which I stopped keeping count. The early 1980s marked both the period of my adolescent hunger for an urbane, grown-up life in New York and the dawn of VHS, enabling the obsessive consumption of movies, which in my case meant the obsessive consumption of movies by Woody Allen.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Karla Cornejo Villavicencio
title: In This Novel, Immigration Status Is Part of the Family Drama
description: “Infinite Country,” by Patricia Engel, follows a mixed-status exodus across the American border.
content: INFINITE COUNTRY By Patricia Engel
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ligaya Mishan
title: How Untamed Branches Are an Apt Symbol for Our Turbulent Times
description: Instead of the cool refinement of a simple bloom, they offer a more imposing and irrepressible sort of beauty.
content: THE QUINCE ARE half-naked, half in flower. The blooms stand out bright white, points of focus in the broad dark, but the branches are the story: the anatomy of spiky boughs, and the angles and cantilevers they contorted themselves into during their life outdoors, reaching for the sun. Some of them are five feet high and set in their ways, resistant to the touch. “You’re wrestling a tiger,” says the New York-based floral designer Emily Thompson, who orchestrated this massing of flora — a vast organic architecture supported only by itself, without steel frames, and only a few zip ties to bind the joints — for the runway of the designer Jason Wu’s fall 2020 fashion show in Manhattan last February, just before the virus took hold of the city.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katharine Q. Seelye
title: Naomi Rosenblum, Historian of Photography, Dies at 96
description: Her seminal works brought scholarship to the field and helped develop appreciation for it as a creative art form.
content: Naomi Rosenblum, who wrote about the history of photography and helped elevate it as an art form, died on Feb. 19 at her home in Long Island City, Queens. She was 96.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Leonhardt
title: Voting Rights or the Filibuster?
description: And what else you need to know today.
content: It’s shaping up to be the most significant question about the new Democratic Senate: If forced to choose between the protection of voting rights and the protection of the filibuster, what will Democrats do?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kate Kelly
title: Goldman Sachs Partners’ Exits Point to a Changing Culture at the Bank
description: An unusually large number of senior executives have left Goldman recently as C.E.O. David Solomon remakes the Wall Street firm.
content: A little more than two years into David M. Solomon’s tenure as chief executive of Goldman Sachs, at least nine senior executives have left or intend to leave soon. It’s an unusually large number for a firm long defined by its tight-knit partnership culture.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Arielle Dollinger and Mihir Zaveri
title: Doctor Who Prescribed Pain Pills Is Charged With 5 Counts of Murder
description: The prosecution on Long Island is one of several across the nation that seek to hold doctors criminally accountable for opioid-related deaths.

content: A former New Orleans police officer with a history of behavioral complaints who was dispatched to help a 14-year-old rape victim get medical attention last year later raped her himself, the girl’s mother claimed in a lawsuit.

title: Malcolm X’s Early Home in Boston Gets U.S. Historic Designation
description: The house where the civil rights leader spent formative teenage years has been added to the National Register of Historic Places.
content: The only remaining childhood home of Malcolm X, a two-and-a-half-story home in the Roxbury section of Boston where he lived as a teenager in the early 1940s, has been added to the National Register of Historic Places.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Weinman
title: Queen Elizabeth II, Amateur Detective
description: This week’s crime fiction column includes SJ Bennett’s new novel, “The Windsor Knot,” in which the monarch investigates a murder at Windsor Castle.
content: I began reading THE WINDSOR KNOT (Morrow, 288 pp., $27.99) in a state of bafflement. Queen Elizabeth II solves mysteries? Is “Lady Caroline Cadwallader” a homage to the celebrated Guardian journalist? Why is Prince Philip behaving so gallantly? But when one character opines that “the problem with Windsor Castle is that it is a dream. Real people only ruin it,” I put aside confusion and surrendered to the sheer entertainment value of SJ Bennett’s first mystery for adults, set as the queen approaches an alternate-reality version of her 90th birthday in 2016.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Inside One Funeral Home in Los Angeles

content: LOS ANGELES — I thought I understood the Covid-19 death toll. Then I started spending time at an East Los Angeles funeral home with the photographer Alex Welsh.

title: Biden Presses Economic Aid Plan, Rejecting Inflation Fears
description: Despite a better-than-expected jobs report, administration officials stressed that millions of workers still needed help from a proposed $1.9 trillion stimulus package.
content: WASHINGTON — With a $1.9 trillion economic aid package on the brink of passing Congress and the pace of vaccinations picking up, some economists, Republican lawmakers and Wall Street traders are increasingly raising a counterintuitive concern: that the economy, still emerging from its precipitous pandemic-induced drop, could be on a path toward overheating.

content: In each installment of The Artists, T highlights a recent or little-seen work by a Black artist, along with a few words from that artist putting the work in context. This week, we’re looking at a clip from the artist Miles Greenberg, who specializes in durational performance art and sculptural forms.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eric Margolis
title: In Japan, His Disaster Art Saves Lives
description: The fight to survive lies at the heart of Kyohei Sakaguchi’s world, whether he is writing self-help books, painting, creating a suicide help line, or designing recycled housing.
content: KUMAMOTO, Japan — A week before the artist, author and architect Kyohei Sakaguchi planned to move into one of his celebrated “zero yen” houses, built from recycled materials, the catastrophic 2011 earthquake struck Japan. A tsunami engulfed the Tohoku region and the Fukushima Daiichi nuclear power plant collapsed. He had recently begun treatment for bipolar disorder. Overwhelmed, he left Tokyo and headed back home to the verdant coastal city of Kumamoto in southwest Japan, and abandoned the recycling project.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Anthes
title: Popular Drug Does Not Alleviate Mild Covid-19 Symptoms, Study Finds
description: Ivermectin, a drug typically used to treat parasitic worms, has been prescribed widely during the coronavirus pandemic, but rigorous data has been lacking.
content: Ivermectin, a controversial anti-parasitic drug that has been touted as a potential Covid-19 treatment, does not speed recovery in people with mild cases of the disease, according to a randomized controlled trial published on Thursday in the journal JAMA.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Medina
title: A Vexing Question for Democrats: What Drives Latino Men to Republicans?
description: Several voters said values like individual responsibility and providing for one’s family, and a desire for lower taxes and financial stability, led them to reject a party embraced by their parents.
content: Erik Ortiz, a 41-year-old hip-hop music producer in Florida, grew up poor in the South Bronx, and spent much of his time as a young adult trying to establish himself financially. Now he considers himself rich. And he believes shaking off the politics of his youth had something to do with it.
source.name: The New York Times

source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roseanna Sommers
title: You Were Duped Into Saying Yes. Is That Still Consent?
description: Legal scholars have long debated this question. Recent psychological studies shed new light.
content: Imagine the following hypothetical situation: Frank and Ellen meet at a night course and end up getting drinks together after class several times. The drinks start to feel like dates, so Ellen asks Frank if he is married, making it clear that adultery is a deal-breaker for her. Frank is married, but he lies and says he is single. The two go to bed. Is Frank guilty of rape?

content: Jason Kilar of CNN’s parent WarnerMedia and Fox Corp.’s Lachlan Murdoch made news yesterday — that’s their business, after all — at a Morgan Stanley conference. The shifting strategies of the media giants are in the spotlight as the Trump era fades, the pandemic approaches its final stages (let’s hope) and billion-dollar deals for sports rights come up for renewal. Here’s what the media moguls said that caught our attention:

content: Cedric Jean-Louis takes no satisfaction in name-calling, but there came a point in the relationship of his friends Renee Smith and Pavel Aspiazu that compelled him to speak frankly. “I finally said, ‘Pavel, you’re an idiot. Renee is an awesome woman,’” he said. In 2018, Mr. Aspiazu wasn’t ready to hear it.

content: The rise of David Mintz from Brooklyn caterer to the multimillionaire who became known as the “P.T. Barnum of tofu” began with a grandmother — not his own, but a 90-year-old woman who happened to walk into his prepared-food takeout grocery one day and apply for a job as a cook.

title: ‘Judas’ Is the Latest Political Movie to Punt on Politics
description: Both “Judas and the Black Messiah” and “BlacKkKlansman” are rooted in issues of radicalism vs. the system, but the dramas rely on morally opaque characters that undermine the stories.
content: At the beginning of the fact-based drama “Judas and the Black Messiah,” an F.B.I. informant named Bill O’Neal (Lakeith Stanfield), wearing a slate gray suit and matching tie, sits in front of a camera. He’s being interviewed for the documentary series “Eyes on the Prize II,” and an unseen questioner asks, “Looking back on your activities in the late ’60s, early ’70s, what would you tell your son about what you did then?” What he did then was abet the police killing of the Black Panther leader Fred Hampton. title: As a Doctor, I Was Skeptical About the Covid Vaccine. Then I Reviewed the Science.
description: How one emergency department doctor shifted her views.
content: As the world records more than two and a half million deaths from the coronavirus and the United States celebrates over 50 million administered vaccines, here at the Royal Melbourne Hospital emergency department, as frontline workers, we scheduled ourselves for our first immunization this week. Australia has not recorded a coronavirus death for months now, and the little outbreaks we have peter out within days because of aggressive lockdowns and a compliant public. Given the low prevalence of disease, Australians have the luxury of choosing not to be vaccinated or to delay the vaccine until we are ready.

My husband and I reacted as though it were going to be 70, and we’d be wearing shorts and drinking gin and tonics. “Let’s have a barbecue!” he suggested. When we actually stepped outside, it was cold. “A chilly 50,” I sighed. We had pasta for dinner.

description: When the revolutionary writer arrived in New York City, he slammed headfirst into a scandal.
content: In April 1906, Czar Nicholas caved in to protests from around the world, and released Maxim Gorky from the prison into which he had thrown him. Mark Twain and other writers, hearing that the celebrated author of “The Lower Depths” had been freed, invited him to New York City, and Gorky, still harassed by the secret police, accepted. With him on the voyage was the actress Maria Andreyeva.

author: By Tim Arango and Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs
title: Derek Chauvin Trial May Be Delayed Over Court Ruling on Third-Degree Murder
description: An appeals court has ruled that a judge must reconsider whether to add a third-degree murder charge against Mr. Chauvin, who is scheduled to go on trial next week for the death of George Floyd.
content: The Minnesota Court of Appeals on Friday ruled that a lower court must reconsider whether to add a third-degree murder charge against Derek Chauvin, the former Minneapolis police officer who is scheduled to go on trial next week for the death of George Floyd.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabeth Vincentelli
title: ‘Boss Level’ Review: Game Never Over
description: Frank Grillo gets to die another day — again and again and again — in the time-loop action comedy.
content: Frank Grillo’s character in “Boss Level” is named Roy Pulver, which must be short for Pulverize because that’s what he does to the assassins out to destroy him. No matter what they try — machete, grenade, Chinese sword, the tight-end Rob Gronkowski machine-gunning from a helicopter — Roy has a parade. Up until he doesn’t and gets killed, only to wake up back in his bed, ready to repeat the exact same ordeal and die another day.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shalini Venugopal Bhagat and Hari Kumar
title: Women Call for India’s Chief Justice to Quit Over Remarks in Rape Cases
description: At one hearing, the head of the Supreme Court asked a 23-year-old accused of raping a minor whether he would marry his victim, who is now an adult.
content: NEW DELHI — Outrage in India is growing over comments made by the nation’s chief justice in two rape cases, with thousands of women signing a letter this week demanding that he resign.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Kliff
title: Private Insurance Wins in Democrats’ First Try at Expanding Health Coverage
description: ‘Medicare for all’ and the public option were hot topics during primary season, but the politics of passing those “gets tricky really fast.”
content: Democrats spent much of the 2020 presidential primary debating the best way to expand public health insurance. They sparred over whether to enroll everyone in public coverage — the preferred policy of Senator Bernie Sanders — or to give everyone a choice to do so, the public option plan that President Biden supports.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Niraj Chokshi
title: The United Airlines engine that failed broke years ahead of its next inspection.
description: That blade was last examined in 2016. After last month’s failure, Pratt & Whitney said it would recommend the inspections every 1,000 flights, according to the N.T.S.B.
content: An airplane engine fan blade that broke during a United Airlines flight last month had thousands of flights remaining before it was due for a federally mandated inspection, the National Transportation Safety Board said on Friday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Kirsch
title: What to Do This Weekend
description: ‘Coming 2 America,’ ‘The Real World’ reunion and other throwbacks.
content: Want to get the At Home newsletter in your inbox? Sign up here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard C. Paddock and Muktita Suhartono
title: Indonesia Says Schools Can’t Make Girls Wear Head Scarves
description: The decree, which applies to public schools in the Muslim-majority country, came after a Christian father confronted an official at his daughter’s school.
content: The father, a Christian, was upset that his 16-year-old daughter had been ordered to wear an Islamic head scarf at her public school in Indonesia. He met with the school’s vice principal and protested the rule. And he didn’t stop there: He streamed their conversation on Facebook Live.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ruth Maclean and Mady Camara
title: Senegal Erupts in Protests, With a Rape Charge Only the Spark
description: After a leading opposition figure, Ousmane Sonko, was accused of rape, demonstrators in one of West Africa’s most stable countries took to the streets to voice their grievances with the president.
content: DAKAR, Senegal — The most widespread demonstrations in Senegal in years continued for the third day on Friday, an expression of anger at the president, Macky Sall, and outrage at the arrest of the country’s leading opposition figure, who has been accused of rape.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carol Schram
title: Top Women’s Hockey Players Renew Their Olympic Journey
description: With the world championship just two months away, a pro tour will play its second event of the year this weekend through a partnership with the Blackhawks.
content: When the United States women’s hockey team won Olympic gold for the first time in 20 years in 2018, the star forward Hilary Knight believed the moment would be a steppingstone to greater visibility for the sport and for more players to have the opportunity to earn a living playing professional hockey.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Eddy
title: German Court Suspends Right to Surveil Far-Right AfD Party
description: The ruling came days after a news report that Germany’s domestic intelligence agency planned to investigate the leading opposition party on suspicion of being a threat to democracy.
content: BERLIN — A German court on Friday suspended the right of the country’s domestic intelligence agency to conduct surveillance of the Alternative for Germany, the leading opposition in Parliament, pending the outcome of a legal challenge by the far-right party.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Isaac
title: Reddit hires its first chief financial officer as it prepares to go public.
description: The addition of Drew Vollero, formerly of Mattel and Snap, is a move toward developing operations more like publicly traded social networks.
content: The world’s most popular internet message board is thinking about going public.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Genzlinger
title: Tony Hendra, a Multiplatform Humorist, Is Dead at 79
description: He took his British brand of satire to nightclubs, TV, film (“This Is Spinal Tap”) and National Lampoon. But a memoir led to a sex-abuse accusation.
content: Tony Hendra, a humorist whose wide-ranging résumé included top editing jobs at National Lampoon and Spy magazines and a zesty role in the mockumentary “This Is Spinal Tap,” died on Thursday in Yonkers, N.Y. He was 79.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Benner
title: A midlevel member of the Trump State Dept. has been arrested on charges related to the Capitol attack.
description: Federico G. Klein is the first member of the Trump administration to face criminal charges in connection with the storming of the Capitol.
content: The F.B.I. said on Thursday that it had arrested a former State Department aide on charges related to the Jan. 6 attack on the Capitol, including unlawful entry, violent and disorderly conduct, obstructing Congress and law enforcement, and assaulting an officer with a dangerous weapon.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jamelle Bouie
title: One Old Way of Keeping Black People From Voting Still Works
description: A promising bill to ensure African-Americans’ civil rights was snuffed out by a Senate filibuster in 1891.
content: This is the story of how a bill to save the vote and preserve a semblance of democracy for millions of Americans died at the hands of an intransigent, reactionary minority in the Senate, which used the filibuster to do its dirty work.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Rogers and Marie Eriel Hobro
title: Surf’s Up. Grab Your Helmet.
description: Helmets used to be a rarity in surfing. Now, young surfers on the North Shore of Oahu are embracing the safety device as a necessity in the world’s most dangerous waves.
content: PUPUKEA, Hawaii — The celebratory mood at the Pipeline surf competition on Oahu’s North Shore shifted quickly.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By J. David Goodman and Danny Hakim
title: Cuomo Aides Rewrote Nursing Home Report to Hide Higher Death Toll
description: The intervention was the earliest action yet known in an effort by Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo that concealed how many nursing home residents died in the pandemic.
content: Top aides to Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo were alarmed: A report written by state health officials had just landed, and it included a count of how many nursing home residents in New York had died in the pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rhea Boyd
title: Black People Need Better Vaccine Access, Not Better Vaccine Attitudes
description: The focus on “hesitancy” as the driver of lower Covid-19 vaccination rates misses the real problem, and opportunity.
content: Despite having one of the highest risks of dying from Covid-19, about twice that of white Americans, Black Americans remain one of the least vaccinated racial or ethnic groups, with data showing that only 5.7 percent have received at least one dose of a Covid-19 vaccine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bill Pennington
title: Arnold Palmer’s Legacy Hints at What Tiger Woods Might Leave Behind
description: The link between the two golf legends feels stronger than ever, and players at the Arnold Palmer Invitational can’t help but make the connection.
content: ORLANDO, Fla. — In a fashion befitting someone born in 1929, Arnold Palmer valued a certain comportment, like men removing their hats when they went indoors. Rory McIlroy, born in 1989, played in the famed Arnold Palmer Invitational for the first time in 2015 and watched with a bit of wonder as the hat protocol was politely enforced in the players’ dining room, sometimes by a smiling Palmer.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Libbey
title: A Road Trip That Ended in Love
description: Kate Googins and Tyler Tetreault weren’t much more than friends when they drove out of Denver. By the time they got to San Diego, both knew their journey was just beginning.
content: When they set out for San Diego from Denver in April 2016, Kate Googins and Tyler Tetreault were not a couple, just two people who had dated briefly six weeks earlier and continued to stay in touch afterward. A little more than halfway through their road trip, outside Sedona, Ariz., they recognized that at some point during their hours of driving they had fallen in love.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Will Wright
title: Can Biden Keep Coal Country From Becoming a ‘Ghost Town’?
description: For nearly 60 years, presidents have promised to lift up Appalachia, but many communities remain on the brink.
content: CUMBERLAND, Ky. — From a porch in Martin County, Ky., in 1964, President Lyndon B. Johnson declared a war on poverty. Decades later, President Barack Obama dedicated millions of dollars to work force development projects in Appalachia. President Donald J. Trump even pledged the impossible: a revival of the region’s faltering coal industry.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tyler Kepner
title: Trea Turner Won’t Steal 75 Bases. He’s Too Good.
description: Washington’s shortstop is the game’s fastest everyday player. He’s so valuable that protecting his body outweighs a 1980s baserunning revival.
content: To illustrate a point about baseball’s most overlooked superstar, Kevin Long reached for statistics no player has bundled in more than a century. Trea Turner, the Washington Nationals shortstop, is the fastest everyday player in the majors. He also hit .335 last season. Those skills can make a coach dream big.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tammy La Gorce
title: A Free Courthouse Wedding? Why Not?
description: After checking out the details, Andrew Campbell and Alejandro Arriaga Ariza decided to take advantage of what a Georgia judge was offering in Atlanta.
content: Andrew Campbell almost passed up the chance to be married for free on Feb. 12 in Atlanta.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victor Mather
title: Creighton Suspends Basketball Coach Over ‘Plantation’ Pep Talk
description: Greg McDermott called his remarks “an awful mistake” and said he had offered to resign. He may return in time for the N.C.A.A. tournament.
content: Greg McDermott, the coach of Creighton’s men’s basketball team, has been suspended on the eve of the N.C.A.A. tournament after he admitted telling his players they needed to “stay on the plantation” in a postgame speech.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robert J. Shiller
title: Making Sense of Elevated Stock Market Prices
description: Shares are very expensive, but so are bonds. Even at current prices, the economist Robert J. Shiller says, it is reasonable to keep some wealth in stocks.
content: The stock market is already quite expensive. That is evident when you compare current stock valuations with those from previous eras.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Brooks
title: How to Love America
description: Patriotism in a time of division.
content: Like you, I’m sure, I love America, but the love has changed. I started out with the child version: America is the greatest and most powerful country on earth.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eric Lipton, Michael Forsythe and Katie Benner
title: Elaine Chao’s Mix of Work and Family Drew Early Ethics Scrutiny
description: An inspector general’s report provided new details of how ethics lawyers at the Transportation Department raised flags starting in 2017 about efforts to promote her family and its shipping business.
content: WASHINGTON — It was late summer 2017, and staff members at the Transportation Department were working feverishly to nail down details for the first planned trip to Asia by their boss, Elaine Chao, a visit that was slated to include meetings with senior government officials in China.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Caron
title: L.G.B.T.Q. People Face Increased Risks From Covid, but Many Don’t Want the Vaccine
description: Evidence suggests that some sexual and gender minorities — especially people of color — are hesitant to get vaccinated due to mistrust of the medical establishment.
content: At her last doctor’s appointment, Erica Tyler, who lives in Brooklyn, N.Y., joked that she didn’t want to get vaccinated for Covid-19 “because another foot might grow out of my forehead. And I’m not ready for that.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Cochrane
title: Action on Stimulus Bill Halts as Senate Clerks Read All 628 Pages Aloud
description: Senator Ron Johnson delayed proceedings on the nearly $2 trillion relief package by demanding that the legislative clerks recite the plan word for word.
content: WASHINGTON — With President Biden’s nearly $2 trillion stimulus bill moving toward passage, Senator Ron Johnson brought proceedings to a halt on Thursday by demanding that Senate clerks recite the 628-page plan word by word, delaying action to register his objections.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jessica Kiang
title: A Dirty Winner at a Lonely Berlin Film Festival
description: The Romanian director Radu Jude’s “Bad Luck Banging or Loony Porn” took the top prize in an online-only edition that lacked the magic of in-person moviegoing.
content: BERLIN — No one wants to read more on the things we miss about going to the movies. Too much has been written about that already — and I can practically hear the pipsqueak sighing of mini-Mr. Stradivarius, stressed out by the demand for his tiny violins. But with the Berlin International Film Festival divided this year into two events — a physical edition to take place in city theaters this summer, and an online press-and-industry portion that unfolded over the past five days — the so-near-yet-so-far contrast between theatrical and home viewing has never been more stark.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman
title: The Avant-Garde Is Alive and Well and Making Fashion
description: Forget playing it safe in the pandemic. Great collections from Marine Serre, Dries Van Noten and Rick Owens.
content: It’s hard to believe that Marine Serre, the 29-year-old French designer whose work was featured in Beyoncé’s “Black is King” visual album and who kicked off Paris Fashion Week with perhaps the most human, immersive, fully realized digital “activation” of the entire fashion month, founded her brand only three years ago.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David E. Sanger
title: For Biden, Deliberation and Caution, Maybe Overcaution, on the World Stage
description: But decisions come more quickly than they did in the Obama administration, when Mr. Biden, as vice president, complained about the endless meetings.
content: President Biden, faced with a decision about how to punish Saudi Arabia for its role in the assassination of a Washington Post journalist, gathered his top national security officials in the Oval Office and pushed them at length about their recommended response. Then he sided with a majority of advisers who argued against the most severe action possible — a direct sanction of Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman, who American intelligence agencies say approved the killing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natalie Muñoz
title: My Two-House, Duffel-Bag Life
description: When my parents divorced, I lost the link that held our family together. And then I found it.
content: I am 15 years old and an only child. People who meet me don’t usually think I’m an only child because I talk with the speed of someone who always had to compete for space in a conversation, as if I have 10 siblings. But no, it’s just me.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brett Anderson
title: Esca, a Seafood Standout in the Theater District, Closes
description: The chef Dave Pasternack, who bought the restaurant from the Batali & Bastianich Hospitality Group, says the location became a liability in the pandemic.
content: Esca, an influential, seafood-focused Italian restaurant in Manhattan’s theater district, has permanently closed, its executive chef and co-owner, Dave Pasternack, said Friday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roy MacGregor
title: Hockey Legend Wayne Gretzky Shared His Father With a Nation
description: Walter Gretzky coached a young Wayne, who ended up setting N.H.L. scoring records that will never be matched, and became a role model for hockey parents.
content: OTTAWA — In an instant 30 years ago, a huge piece of Walter Gretzky’s legacy went missing.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Analysis: Biden’s early foreign policy decisions exhibit restraint and quick deliberation.

author: By Ben Casselman and Jim Tankersley
title: When Amazon Raises Its Minimum Wage, Local Companies Follow Suit
description: New research suggests that when big companies increase wages, they drive up pay in the places where they operate — without a notable loss in jobs.
content: Amazon has embarked on an advertising blitz this winter, urging Congress to follow the company’s lead and raise the federal minimum wage to $15 an hour. American workers “simply can’t wait” for higher pay, the company said in a recent blog post.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julie Bosman, Michael D. Shear and Reid J. Epstein
title: As Biden Urges Caution on Covid, Governors Split on How Fast to Reopen
description: Even within political parties, governors were taking different approaches as they tried to balance public health guidance with residents’ eagerness to get back to normal life.
content: Despite President Biden’s sharp criticism of Texas and Mississippi for abruptly removing mask mandates, states and cities are aggressively going their own ways on Covid-19 restrictions as they decide when and how to reopen their economies.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paula Span
title: Can Long-Term Care Employers Require Staff Members to Be Vaccinated?
description: As legal experts and ethicists debate, some companies aren’t waiting.
content: For much of the winter, Meryl Gordon worried about the people caring for her 95-year-old mother, who was rehabbing in a Manhattan nursing home after surgery for a broken hip.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Maslin Nir
title: Furor in Rochester After Police Pepper-Spray Mother With Toddler
description: A woman accused of shoplifting was sprayed with a chemical irritant and knocked to the ground in front of her daughter, the latest altercation between the police and Black residents.
content: A Rochester, N.Y., police officer tackled and used pepper spray on a woman who had been accused of shoplifting and was with her young daughter last month, according to police body-camera videos of the episode that were released on Friday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Giovanni Russonello
title: QAnon Proves Its Resilience
description: Worries about an enduring, violent conspiracy theory rise anew.
content: Tumbleweeds blew through the House chambers today, after Speaker Nancy Pelosi moved a major vote to Wednesday night, so that lawmakers could skip town a day early.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Kazuo Ishiguro and Friendship With Machines
description: Radhika Jones discusses Ishiguro’s “Klara and the Sun,” and Mark Harris talks about “Mike Nichols: A Life.”
content: Kazuo Ishigruo’s eighth novel, “Klara and the Sun,” is his first since he won the Nobel Prize for Literature in 2017. It’s narrated by Klara, an Artificial Friend — a humanoid machine who acts as a companion for a 14-year-old child. Radhika Jones, the editor of Vanity Fair, talks about the novel and where it fits into Ishiguro’s august body of work on this week’s podcast.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Fandos
title: Former Impeachment Manager Sues Trump Over Capitol Riot
description: The suit by Representative Eric Swalwell accuses Donald J. Trump of inciting the Jan. 6 attack and conspiring to prevent Congress from formalizing President Biden’s victory.
content: A House Democrat who unsuccessfully prosecuted Donald J. Trump at his impeachment trial sued him in federal court on Friday for acts of terrorism and incitement to riot, trying to use the justice system to punish the former president for his role in the Jan. 6 assault on the Capitol.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bijal P. Trivedi
title: The Everyday Chemicals That Might Be Leading Us to Our Extinction
description: In “Count Down,” Shanna Swan tells a story of declining sperm count, rising infertility and the possible extinction of the human species.
content: COUNT DOWN How Our Modern World Is Altering Male and Female Reproductive Development, Threatening Sperm Counts, and Imperiling the Future of the Human RaceBy Shanna H. Swan with Stacey Colino
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katherine Schulten
title: What Volunteer Work Would You Most Like to Do?
description: Many teenagers have to meet school service requirements, but the pandemic has made doing so more difficult. What will you choose?
content: Have you found a way to volunteer this past year, even in the midst of a global pandemic? If so, what did you do, and how did you find your job? Have you enjoyed it?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Corinna da Fonseca-Wollheim
title: A Composer’s Notes Echo After His Death
description: The violinist Hilary Hahn has released the premiere recording of two serenades by Einojuhani Rautavaara, who died in 2016.
content: When the Finnish composer Einojuhani Rautavaara died in 2016, at 87, a voice of rare lyricism in contemporary music fell silent. His death severed a link to the past: Rautavaara had been a protégé of Sibelius, Finland’s master composer, and one of the pallbearers at his funeral in 1957. Rautavaara’s music, too, conjured the past. Though he entertained some modernist techniques, at core his style was seductively, if idiosyncratically, Romantic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rory Smith
title: Perfection, Art and Manchester City
description: Pep Guardiola’s team has won 15 straight Premier League games and hasn’t lost to anyone since November. But can clinical still qualify as cool?
content: The Equitable Building was supposed to be the last of Manhattan’s skyscrapers. When it opened in 1915, it cast — in a very real sense — everything around it into shadow: a 555-foot neoclassical cliff rising sheer from the street between Pine and Cedar, looming over Broadway, condemning a swath of the Financial District to a life of permanent shadow.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maya Phillips
title: Comfort Viewing: 3 Reasons I Love ‘Courage the Cowardly Dog’
description: The bizarre animated series creatively blended the beautiful with the grotesque, pop culture with pathos.
content: In another life I would have written a book called “Of Monsters and Mutts.” Why? Well, I can’t help my love for scaredy-cat canines who are bedeviled by the scary and supernatural. As a child, I gleefully watched every incarnation of Scooby-Doo I could find, including the original “Scooby-Doo Where Are You?” TV series. So when “Courage the Cowardly Dog” appeared on Cartoon Network in 1999, I was already primed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sandra E. Garcia
title: A High B.M.I. Can Get You Vaccinated Earlier, Junk Science or Not
description: A body mass index, or B.M.I., that indicates a risk for obesity can qualify someone for the Covid-19 vaccine, even if the measurement is outdated.
content: Rebecca O’Neal didn’t believe she qualified for a Covid-19 vaccine. She had not realized that her turn had come. Last week, when she scrolled through the eligibility requirements for the state of New York, she noticed body mass index on the list.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Poniewozik
title: ‘The Real World’ Revisited: When Reality Had Bite
description: The nostalgic reunion series is surprisingly polite. But on a rewatch, the original season is still an eye-opening piece of TV and social history.
content: Gather ’round, children, and let Grandpa Gen X tell you what life was like back in nineteen-dickety-ninety-two, when telephones were tethered to the wall by wires, nickels had pictures of bumblebees on them and reality TV was something new and shocking.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vivian Marino
title: Jean Kennedy Smith’s Duplex Is Up for Sale
description: Ms. Smith, who died last June, was the last surviving sibling of President John F. Kennedy. She moved into the apartment at 4 Sutton Place after serving as ambassador to Ireland.
content: Jean Kennedy Smith’s grand Manhattan duplex overlooking the East River, where she played host to her large, prominent family, along with luminaries from political, art and showbiz circles, is being sold by her estate. The asking price is $6.45 million, with $19,975 in monthly maintenance.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vivian Wang
title: China subjects some travelers to anal swabs, angering foreign governments.
description: Some experts have questioned the need for the tests, saying that nasal and throat swabs are still the most effective because the coronavirus is contracted through the respiratory tract.
content: China is requiring some travelers arriving from overseas to receive an invasive anal swab test as part of its coronavirus containment measures, a move that has outraged and shocked several foreign governments.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Caldwell
title: Is This the End of French Intellectual Life?
description: The country’s culture of argument has come under the sway of a more ideological, more identity-focused model imported from the United States.
content: At the end of last summer, Le Débat, France’s most prestigious intellectual review, accompanied its 40th-anniversary issue with a wholly unexpected announcement: It would cease publication forthwith. Le Débat and its three or four thousand loyal readers had maintained an allegiance to the political left since the Cold War — but the meaning of “left” has been shifting. Rivals now claim the term, particularly social movements that arose in France in the 1980s to champion what is variously called identity politics or social justice. After waging a decades-long twilight struggle against these movements, Le Débat has lost.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lesley Evans Ogden
title: Largest Glowing Shark Species Discovered Near New Zealand
description: It’s the biggest bioluminescent vertebrate found on land or sea, so far.
content: As they prowl the oceans, sharks aren’t just hunting. Some of them are glowing. And now researchers have identified the largest glow-in-the-dark species with a spine — on land or sea — that has ever been found.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Segal
title: The Pandemic Needs Its Smokey Bear
description: Instead it has a nearly empty hotel for Covid patients in London, celebrities in masks — and no public health message that has broken through.
content: Newham, a borough of northeast London, is known as the main site of the 2012 Summer Olympics and as home to an immigrant community that speaks more than 100 languages. Last year, it added a less flattering distinction. From March to December, it had the highest coronavirus death rate of anywhere in England or Wales — 328 deaths per 100,000 people.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Mealtime
description: What do you think this image is saying?
source.name: The New York Times

description: Quotation of the Day for Friday, March 5, 2021.

author: By Clay Risen
title: Priscilla Read Chenoweth, Who Won Freedom for a Stranger, Dies at 90
description: She spent seven years and much of her retirement savings to prove that a teenager had been wrongly convicted of murder.
content: Priscilla Read Chenoweth, a civil rights activist and lawyer who spent seven years and tens of thousands of dollars of her own money to exonerate a stranger wrongly convicted of second-degree murder, died on Feb. 16 at her home in Silver Spring, Md. She was 90.

title: More Democrats join the effort to kill the filibuster as a way of saving Biden’s agenda.
description: The mood in the party is shifting quickly, as fears grow that Republicans will block Mr. Biden’s biggest plans
content: A growing number of Senate Democrats are warming to the idea of eliminating the filibuster as they encounter Republican resistance to President Biden’s legislative agenda, forcing the White House to cut deals on issues like the minimum wage and pandemic relief payments.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vincent M. Mallozzi
title: A ‘Hero’ Helped Her Find Her Footing
description: When Nicole Saracino first met Stephen Hayman, she was a week away from an ankle surgery. Mr. Hayman didn’t mind being the one she leaned on.
content: A week before Nicole Saracino had surgery on her right ankle in May 2017, she logged onto her dating profile and clicked Stephen Hayman into her life.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Bahr
title: Kelly Marie Tran: ‘I’m Not Afraid Anymore’
description: The actress has left the “Star Wars” bullies behind to star as Disney’s first Southeast Asian princess in “Raya and the Last Dragon.” She says, “I’m finally asking for the things I want.”
content: There are two Kelly Marie Trans in this story.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Kenigsberg
